text:
A value that controls how much of the game world is visible on the screen. Also known as Field of View.
In Minecraft, the FOV value represents how many degrees of vertical vision the player gets without modifying effects such as sprinting, flying or status effects. Note that other games' FOV setting might represent different angles, meaning that using the same FOV value across different games can yield different results. The table below shows how Minecraft's FOV setting affects horizontal field of view in different display aspect ratios.
Setting
name Setting value
(vertical FOV) Resulting horizontal field of view
4:3
aspect ratio 16:9
aspect ratio
30° 39.3° 50.9°
40° 51.8° 65.8°
50° 63.7° 79.3°
60° 75.2° 91.5°
Normal 70° 86.1° 102.4°
80° 96.4° 112.3°
90° 106.3° 121.3°
100° 115.6° 129.5°
Quake Pro 110° 124.6° 137.0°

Set the difficulty level from the choice of Peaceful, Easy, Normal, and Hard. If the padlock is clicked and confirmed, the difficulty on that world cannot be changed without commands. (Note that the difficulty cannot be changed if playing Hardcore Mode. On a server, difficulty can be changed only by commands or editing the server.properties file.)
Only visible when in a world.
Varies on difficulty set on current world or server; defaults to Normal on Create New World screen.
Toggles whether the player name will show up in server listings.
Toggles the difficulty of the server.
Toggles the cape. If set to off, the cape texture for wearing a pair of Elytra would also be deactivated.
Toggles the left arm second layer.
Toggles the right arm second layer.
Toggles the left leg second layer.
Toggles the right leg second layer.
Switches the main hand, between left and right.
The volume of gameplay music, which is stopped by switching to OFF
The volume of music and sounds played from Jukeboxes and Note Blocks
The volume of rain and thunder
The volume of blocks (pistons, chests, doors, etc.)
The volume of hostile and neutral mobs (except slimes and magma cubes)
The volume of passive mobs and non-mob entities like minecarts, as well as slimes and magma cubes
The volume of players (item plops, hurt sounds, etc.)
The volume of Ambience, sound of entering/exiting water and fireworks
The volume of speech in Minecraft (for map makers)

OFF defaults to stereo sound.
ON uses HRTF (head related transfer function) based directional audio to improve simulation of 3D sound, which requires HRTF-compatible hardware and is best experienced when using headphones.
Sets the resolution and framerate of the game when playing in fullscreen.
Sets the distance of color transitions between biomes.

Fabulous! graphics uses screen shaders for drawing weather, clouds and particles behind translucent blocks and water. This may severely impact performance for portable devices and 4K displays.
Fancy enables higher quality graphic effects. Graphic effects include transparent leaves, increased rain particles, a black vignette around the screen in darker areas, and the world border red warning vignette effect.
Fast disables those effects for better performance.

The render distance controls how many chunks of the world are visible at once. The fewer chunks that are included, the faster each frame can be rendered, resulting in higher frames per second (FPS).
The most distant terrain is faded into the sky color as if by fog, to avoid a sharp edge to the visible world; so this option is also known as "fog".
The maximum value is 32 for 64-bit Java installs with at least 1 gigabyte of memory, and 16 in all other cases.
Note: diameter = radius × 2 + 1
Name View distance (radius)
[show]
Total count

Determines which chunk sections are updated synchronously during a single frame.
Threaded has nearby chunks compiled in parallel threads, which may result in visual holes when blocks are destroyed.
Semi Blocking has chunks recompile immediately when some actions occur, including placing or destroying blocks.
Fully Blocking defaults to the behavior used prior to Java Edition 1.18, in which chunks always compile immediately, which may affect performance when placing or destroying blocks.

Simulation distance is similar to render distance, but affects the number of chunks in which entities are updated, and blocks and fluids are ticked. Simulation distance is more taxing on performance than the equivalent level of render distance. The available values are the same as render distance, except the minimum value is 5 chunks.

Lighting is smoothed across the blocks (ambient occlusion) or each block has a distinctive light level. This setting does not change the gameplay in any way, but it has a slight effect on performance.
Limits the FPS. Limiting the framerate to a multiple of the player monitor's refresh rate can save processing power.

Limits the player's frames per second to the screen's refresh rate, which is usually 60 Hz, 75 Hz, or 120 to 240 Hz on some gaming-targeted screens. Enabling VSync fixes tearing, but increases input latency and causes stuttering if one's computer cannot draw enough frames per second.
Toggles the "bobbing" motion of the camera as the player is walking. Disabling it may increase performance.

Controls the GUI (Graphical User Interface) scale. This also controls the HUD (Heads Up Display) size. Note that the options available to the player depends on the game resolution. A GUI scale of 4 is avaiable only at resolutions of 1280×960 or higher, a GUI scale of 3 is available only at resolutions of 960×720 or higher, a GUI scale of 2 is available only at resolutions of 640×480 or higher, a GUI scale of 1 is properly scaled up until a window resolution of 310x250 but smaller resolutions under can cause elements to run offscreen. Auto sets the GUI scale to the highest value available for the current resolution.

OFF No attack indicator renders.
Crosshair A little gray translucent bar appears below the crosshair displaying attack power.
Hotbar A little gray sword bar appears on the side of the hotbar (on the same side as the player's main hand) displaying attack power.
Dims down or lights up the game's surfaces, even if fully dark. It has no effect on gameplay, it is a visual effect. Works in any dimension and affects the Night Vision status effect.

Fancy causes the clouds to be rendered in 3D.
Fast causes the clouds to be rendered flat.
OFF causes no clouds to be rendered.
Puts Minecraft into Fullscreen mode, keeping it off keeps it in a window. Can also be changed with F11.

All allows all particles.
Decreased reduces the amount of particles for some particle events.
Minimal reduces particles further and disables some non-essential particles.
The higher the level, the more the textures look "smooth". See File:Mipmap comparison.png for a comparison of the four mipmap levels and without mipmap.
Determines whether entities display simple shadows.
Changes the distortion effects (e.g. Nausea and nether portal distortion).

Adjusts the distance that entities can be seen as a percentage of 160 blocks.
Name
[show]
Entity distance (radius)

↑ Values beyond 32 are not available in game and can only be accessed through options.txt or third-party programs.
Changes the FOV effects of anything affecting them.
Enables automatically jumping when the player walks near a block with a block of air above.
Changes the sensitivity of the mouse when looking in-game.
Inverts vertical axis of the mouse when looking in-game.
Changes the sensitivity of the scroll wheel in-game. Values above 1 do not affect selecting items in the Hotbar.
Tells the game to ignore scroll magnitude values given by the operating system and instead to act as if the operating system supplied −1 or +1.
Toggles touchscreen mode, intended for touchscreen devices.

Takes the mouse input directly, instead of from the mouse cursor. This means that mouse movement is not affected by cursor acceleration or scaling, such as Windows' built in "Enhace pointer precision" and "Pointer speed".

ON Unicode Font
OFF ASCII Font

Shown enables the player's ability to see the chat on a server.
Commands Only allows the player to see only the output of commands in the chat.
Hidden hides the chat on all servers.

ON allows the player to see the chat in many different colors.
OFF disables this function and allows the player to see the chat only in a white color.

ON allows the player to see URLs and other links in the chat.
OFF disables this function and blocks all URLs and other links.

ON forces a prompt to appear on the player's screen whenever they click on a URL to makes sure that they wish to exit Minecraft and head to the website.
OFF turns the prompt off.
The opacity of the chat text.
The opacity of the text background.
How large the chat is shown.
The max width that the chat may appear.
The max height that the chat is allowed to appear when in focus (chat input and history open).
The max height that the chat is allowed to appear normally (chat input and history closed).

All narrates everything.
Chat narrates chat & system.
System narrates system.
OFF Narrates nothing.
Toggles if command suggestions show up or not, if off the player has to press tab to bring them up.
Toggles if the game will attempt to apply chat hiding by matching the text in messages.
Toggles reduced information on the debug screen.
Toggles whether the narrator narrates all text, text in chat only, or text in menus only.
The opacity of the background behind text.
Toggles whether the background behind text is restricted to chat or used everywhere.
Changes the amount of spacing between text.
Enables automatically jumping when the player passes near a one block high wall.
Changes the distortion effects (e.g. Nausea and nether portal distortion).
Changes the FOV effects of anything affecting them.
Changes the Mojang Studios loading screen color from red to black.
Prevents the screen from flashing when lightning strikes. The lightning bolts themselves are still visible.
Changes how dark the Darkness effect gets when a warden or sculk shrieker gives it to the player. Fog distance remains unaffected.
Allows Minecraft to download resource packs from the server.
Text To Speech with Device Settings[note 2]
Toggle to read and speak background menus.
Toggle to speak the chat messages and commands.
Toggle to open chat message notification.
Toggle how the camera shakes visually.
Toggles to set the cursor to the center

Snap Allows to turn the camera by periodic steps.
Classic Allows the player to move the camera freely.
Wheel Allows to turn the camera by rotating Right Stick in a circle.
Snap Wheel Allows to turn the camera in pre-determined angles by rotating Right Stick in a circle.
Toggles the size of each camera movement.
Toggles the size of each camera movement should change based on how far the player pushes Right Stick.
Toggles sound to play each time the camera direction is changed.

Linear When turned on, the player's velocity is constant with all acceleration/deceleration disabled.
Classic The player accelerates/decelerates normally in VR mode.

Linear All acceleration/deceleration is removed from the jump. The jump height is also reduced so that it is the same height as a block instead of slightly higher.
Classic The player jumps normally in VR mode.
Toggles the auto-jump feature, while on Immersive Mode.

Follow Gaze The player's direction of motion follows the player
Follow Player Angle The direction of motion is independent of the player viewpoint.

Lock-On Mining is locked to a specific block when the player starts mining.
Disabled The cursor moves freely in the environment as the player shifts the gaze while mining.

Drift The HUD is allowed to “float” for comfort.
Fixed The HUD is fixed on the screen.
Controls how far from the center of the player's vision the HUD displays.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning while using spyglass.
Changes the sensitivity of the mouse inside the UI in VR mode.
Toggles inversion of camera when looking up/down.
Chooses the keyboard layout to use.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning while using spyglass.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning in VR.
Toggles inversion of camera when looking up/down.
Toggles to hide the controller hints.
Chooses whether to swap the position of / button (/ Buttons on PlayStation).
Chooses whether to swap the position of / button (/ Button Swap on PlayStation).
Changes the sensitivity of the controller cursor when turning.
Toggles the auto-jump feature while in VR mode.
Chooses the controller layout to use.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning.
Changes the sensitivity of the camera when turning while using spyglass.
Toggles inversion of camera when looking up/down.
ON on mobile, OFF on other platforms
Chooses whether to use the touchscreen to interact throughout the screen or use a crosshair.
Toggles the D-pad being on the left/right side of the screen.
Chooses whether to swap the position of jump and sneak buttons.
Chooses whether to use the touch for hotbar only.
Changes the size of the buttons.
Changes the player's gamertag. Visible when player is signed in.
Manages the player's account. Visible when player is signed in.
Manage who can send your Invites
Manages the player's invites. Visible when player is signed in.
Sign Out of your Microsoft Account
Sign out of the player's account. Visible when player is signed in.
Toggle to auto update the new unlocked packs.
ON on other platforms, ON with Wi-Fi Only on mobile devices
Toggle to replace custom skins of other player to default skins.
Opens to the licensed content site.
Shows the Noto Sans font license.
Adjusts the brightness of the game.
Toggles the resolution of the game when playing in fullscreen.
Toggles to hide the player hand.
Toggles the side-view of the player displayed in the top-left corner of the screen.
Toggles the animations when switching UI or menus.
Toggles the opacity of the HUD.
Toggles the opacity of the HUD, while in split screen.
Adjusts the position of the game screen.
Toggles between the horizontal and vertical orientation of the splitscreen.
Toggles the outline selection of the block.
ON on other platforms, OFF on mobile devices
Toggles the player name text, while in split screen.
Chooses whether to show the bobbing when walking.
Toggle how the camera shakes visually.
Toggles the sun, moon, clouds, stars and sky color.

Toggles fancy graphics.
Note that clouds on fast graphics remain volumetric but become opaque.
FOV Can Be Altered By Gameplay
Toggles whether gameplay affects FOV changes.
Changes the game UI style between classic (desktop UI) and Pocket UI.
Varies on different platforms, defaults to Pocket on mobile devices such as Android and iOS, and defaults to Classic on other platforms.
Controls the GUI (Graphical User Interface) scale. This also controls the HUD (Heads Up Display) size.
Boosts frame rates on GeForce RTX graphics cards with NVIDIA DLSS 2.0.
Toggles the ray tracing on or off.

Changes the render distance of the terrain, and also affects the render distance of foliage such as transparent leaves, crops and animated textures. Available in 2-10 sections on the slider, ranging from 4-96 chunks maximum (depending on the device).
Controls the chunk render distance of ray tracing if "Ray Tracing" option is on.

Toggles the amount of anti aliasing, which smooths the image and removes jagged edges.
2x MSAA
4x MSAA
8x MSAA
Choose the volume level of all sounds.
Choose the volume level of the gameplay music.
Choose the volume level of gameplay sounds.
Choose the volume level of Ambience, sound of entering/exiting water and fireworks.
Choose the volume level of blocks (anvils, chests, doors, etc.).
Choose the volume level of hostile and neutral mobs.
Choose the volume level of passive mobs.
Choose the volume level of players (item plops, hurt sounds, etc.).
Choose the volume level of music and sounds played from Jukeboxes and Note Blocks.
Choose the volume level of rain and thunder.
Choose the volume level of text to speech.
Pressing F cycles between four levels of render distance.
Added GUI size and Advanced OpenGL settings.
Added a Performance section in Video Settings.
The Brightness setting was added, teased earlier that July.[1] Options for remapping block place/use and block destroy/attack were added.
The side of grass blocks is now always tinted regardless of graphics settings.
The Clouds setting was added (however, texture packs were able to remove them before this option was introduced).
The options menu was improved with a new "Chat Settings" menu.
Added new Full-screen toggle to the Video settings.
Added new use Vsync toggle in the Video settings.
Added an option to toggle touchscreen mode.
Moved Texture Packs setting from the main menu to the options menu.
The options menu was revamped, including a brand new layout, new key binds and a "Super Secret Settings" button in the menu.
The "Super Secret Settings" button now plays a random sound when clicked.

The "Super Secret Settings" button now creates a shader effect on the game's display, in the following order: FXAA, Art, Bumpy, Blobs_2, Pencil, Color_Convolve, Deconverge, Flip, Invert, NTSC, Outline, Phosphor, Scan_Pincushion, Sobel, Bits, Desaturate, Green, Blur, Wobble, Blobs, Antialias, Default.
Replaced the render distance "cycle" button with a slider ranging from 2 to 16 chunks.
Added a max framerate slider option.
Added "Twitch Broadcast Settings" and "Twitch Chat Settings" buttons.
Server Resource Packs option is now per-server, and has three settings: Prompt, Enabled, and Disabled.
The minimum FOV setting is now 30 rather than 70.
Dropped items on Fast graphics now face the player on all three axes, rather than just xz.
Due to the introduction of proper item models, dropped items now always render in 3D, rather then just while on fancy graphics.
The render distance slider now goes to 32 on machines running 64-bit Java with at least 1 gigabyte of available memory.
The option to enable entity shadows is now controlled separately from the standard fast and fancy graphics.
The cloud's "fast" and "fancy" shape are controlled by the same option that enables clouds, rather than by the standard fast and fancy graphics.
Removed Alternate Blocks from video settings.
Added "Main Hand" to the skin settings.
Added "Attack Indicator" to the video settings.
Added "Voice/Speech" to the music & sound settings.
Options when editing a world to make a backup and open the backups folder.
An option in chat settings to toggle automatic command suggestions (defaults on, otherwise hit tab to bring them up).
Disabled the "Allow Snooper" button in Snooper Settings, defaulting to being off. Was done to comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).[2]
Along with Snooper Settings getting disabled, the list of data shown is shortened drastically.
Option Fullscreen resolution capitalization changed to Fullscreen Resolution.
Removed "Use VBOs" from video settings. VBOs are now always used.
Removed "Snooper Settings" after not being able to enable it since 18w21a. Configurable only in options.txt.
The Tab ↹ key now cycles through the options.
Added "Sprint" and "Sneak" toggles to accessibility settings.
Added functionality to import/export world settings.

Changed tooltip description for the "Fabulous!" graphics option from
"Fabulous" graphics enables screen shaders to draw translucent objects per-pixel.
This may severely impact performance for portable devices and 4k displays.
to
Fabulous! graphics uses screen shaders for drawing weather, clouds and particles behind translucent blocks and water.
This may severely impact performance for portable devices and 4K displays.

Changed tooltip description for the "Fancy" graphics option from:
"Fancy" graphics balances performance and quality for the majority of machines.
to
Fancy graphics balances performance and quality for the majority of machines.
Weather, clouds, and particles may not appear behind translucent blocks or water.
Removed quotations from "Fast" and changed "tree-leaves" to "leaves" from the tooltip description for the "Fast" graphics option.
Added "Distortion Effects" and "FOV effects" sliders to video and accessibility settings.
"Chat Delay" is now also available in chat settings.
Added new "Hide Matched Names" to chat settings.
Added "Hide Lightning Flashes" to accessibility settings.
Moved keyboard controls into "Key Binds", which remain under controls.
Added "Simulation Distance" to video settings. This setting affects the entity update distance which was previously determined by "Render Distance".
The default brightness has been changed from "Moody" to 50.
Block and fluid ticking distance moved from "Render Distance" to "Simulation Distance". The minimum simulation distance is raised from 2 to 5 chunks.
Added Online Options as a separate screen, with the "Realms Notifications" option being moved to this screen.
Added "Allow Server Listings" and "Server Difficulty" to online options.
Added "Directional Audio" to the music & sound settings.
"Darkness Effect" setting is not added yet in this non-experimental snapshot.
Redesigned options menu. There are now four sections in the menu, game, controls, graphics, and sound.
Removed option for smooth lighting. It is now always on.
Added far (256 blocks) and farthest (400 blocks) render distances.
By default, fancy graphics is now on.
View distance on Android is no longer limited to 3 sliders.
Added the brightness slider. It is located in the graphics menu.
Gamemode can be changed in the world edit menu.
On creative mode worlds, the daylight cycle can be locked to day.
Added option to swap jump and sneak.
Multiplayer can now be disabled in the options menu.
Removed sound section in the options menu. The volume slider is now in the Game section.
On the title screen, the options icon is no longer a wrench.
Made the options icon slightly bigger.
Added "Fancy Leaves", "Anti-Aliasing", and "Particle Render Distance" option to the video settings on Windows 10.
Added "Audio Settings", "Keyboard and Mouse Settings", "Controller Settings", and "Profile" settings.
Added "Camera Perspective" option to the video settings.
Added "UI Profile" option to change between classic and pocket UI.
Added "Text To Speech for Chat" option.
Added "Change Screen Safe Area" option to the video settings.
Classic UI now repositions the health, hunger, oxygen, and armor bars to above the hotbar instead of the top of the screen, making it like Java Edition and Legacy Console Edition.
Added "Smooth Lighting" to the video settings.
Added "Require Encrypted Websockets" to the profile settings.
Added "Hide HUD", "Hide Hand", "Outline Selection", "In-game Player Names", "HUD Opacity", "Hide Paper Doll", "Show Autosave Icon", and "Render Clouds" to the video settings.
Added "FOV Can Be Altered By Gameplay" option to the video settings
Added "Licensed Content" button to the profile settings.
Added "Controller Cursor Sensitivity" option to the controller controls settings.
Added "Screen Animation" option to the video settings.
Added "Touch only affects hotbar" option to the touch controls settings.
Added "A/B Button Swap" and "X/Y Button Swap" option to the controller controls settings.
Added "Full Keyboard Gameplay" toggle to the Keyboard & Mouse settings.
Added "Fancy Bubbles" to the video settings.
Added "Enable UI Screen Reader" to the accessibility settings.
Added "Enable Open Chat Message" to the accessibility settings.
Added "Credits" button to the profile settings.
Added "Enable Text To Speech with Device Settings" to the accessibility settings.
Added "Only Allow Trusted Skins" option to the profile settings.
Added advanced video settings along with "Upscaling" and "DirectX Ray Tracing".

Moved "View Bobbing", "Fancy Leaves", "Fancy Bubbles", "Render Clouds", "Beautiful Skies", "Smooth Lighting", "Fancy Bubbles", "Fancy Graphics", "Render Distance", "Particle Render Distance", and "Anti-Aliasing" options to advanced video settings.
Added "Text Background Opacity" to the accessibility settings.
Added "Font License" button to the profile settings.
Removed "Particle Render Distance" option to the video settings.
Added "Camera Shake" to the accessibility and video settings.
Added "Sound", "Ambient/Environment", "Blocks", "Hostile Creatures", "Friendly Creatures", "Players", "Jukeboxes/Note Blocks", and "Weather" to the audio settings.
Added "Upscaling" and "Ray Tracing" to the video settings, ported from the RTX Beta.
Renamed "Master Volume" to "Main" in the Audio settings.
Added text-to-speech setting to the Audio settings.
Broadcasting options are now completely removed from the game again, since Mixer streaming services are no longer available.
Added "Spyglass Damping" scale option ranging from 0 to 100.
Added Creator settings which currently has content log settings.
Added "Clear Hotbar" option to the controller settings.

texts.text: Not to be confused with Main menu.
For the command line options, see Tutorials/Setting up a server § Minecraft options.
Minecraft's user environment can be configured through the Options setting. A few additional options can be changed only by editing the options.txt file manually.

Selecting Options brings up the main options page:
This is only visible in the main menu or when on a server.
From the main Options page, one can click down to Controls for these additional settings:
Allows players to change the language that is viewed by their client.
Allows the player to change their resource pack settings.
These settings are available only on Oculus Rift, Windows Mixed Reality, and PlayStation 4 and 5 while using the PlayStation VR device.
Allows the player to change their resource & behavior pack settings.
Allows the player to delete or change the worlds, resource and behavior packs, cached data, and world template.
Choose the langauges in-game to use.
Note: This video dates from release Java Edition 1.5, and so does not show all options currently available.
|Added an option to change the full-screen resolution.}}
